Problem 2

Let AAA be invertible.

  1. Show that AtA^tAt is invertible.
  2. Prove that (At)−1=(A−1)t\p{A^t}^{-1} = \p{A^{-1}}^t(At)−1=(A−1)t.
Solution.

We will do both parts at the same time by giving a left and right inverse for AtA^tAt. Recall that

(AB)t=BtAt.\p{AB}^t = B^t A^t.(AB)t=BtAt.

Note that the order of multiplication is reversed when we take transposes. Since AAA is invertible, A−1A^{-1}A−1 exists and

{AA−1=In,A−1A=In.\begin{cases} AA^{-1} = I_n, \\ A^{-1}A = I_n. \end{cases}{AA−1=In​,A−1A=In​.​

Since Int=InI_n^t = I_nInt​=In​, transposing both sides of the equations above yields

{(A−1)tAt=(AA−1)t=Int=In,At(A−1)t=(A−1A)t=Int=In.\begin{cases} \p{A^{-1}}^tA^t = \p{AA^{-1}}^t = I_n^t = I_n, \\ A^t\p{A^{-1}}^t = \p{A^{-1}A}^t = I_n^t = I_n. \end{cases}{(A−1)tAt=(AA−1)t=Int​=In​,At(A−1)t=(A−1A)t=Int​=In​.​

In summary,

(A−1)tAt=At(A−1)t=In.\p{A^{-1}}^tA^t = A^t\p{A^{-1}}^t = I_n.(A−1)tAt=At(A−1)t=In​.

AtA^tAt has a left and right inverse, so it's invertible, and we have shown that the left and right inverse are both (A−1)t\p{A^{-1}}^t(A−1)t, i.e., (At)−1=(A−1)t\p{A^t}^{-1} = \p{A^{-1}}^t(At)−1=(A−1)t.

Problem 6

Let AAA and BBB be n×nn \times nn×n matrices such that AB=InAB = I_nAB=In​.

  1. Prove that AAA and BBB are invertible.
  2. Prove that A=B−1A = B^{-1}A=B−1 and B=A−1B = A^{-1}B=A−1.
  3. State and prove analogous results for linear transformations defined on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
Solution.

  1. Note that AAA is surjective: given w∈Fnw \in \F^nw∈Fn, we have

    (AB)w=Inw=w  ⟹  A(Bw)=w\p{AB}w = I_nw = w \implies A\p{Bw} = w(AB)w=In​w=w⟹A(Bw)=w

    since matrix multiplication is associative. If we set v=Bw∈Fnv = Bw \in \F^nv=Bw∈Fn, then Av=wAv = wAv=w, so because www was arbitrary, this shows that AAA is surjective.

    Because AAA is a square matrix, surjective is equivalent to invertible, so AAA is invertible.

  2. Now that we know that AAA is invertible, we know that A−1A^{-1}A−1 exists. Thus, multiplying both sides of AB=InAB = I_nAB=In​ by A−1A^{-1}A−1,

    A−1AB=A−1In  ⟹  B=A−1.A^{-1}AB = A^{-1}I_n \implies B = A^{-1}.A−1AB=A−1In​⟹B=A−1.

    Hence, BBB is equal to the invertible matrix A−1A^{-1}A−1, so BBB itself is invertible with B−1=(A−1)−1=AB^{-1} = \p{A^{-1}}^{-1} = AB−1=(A−1)−1=A.

  3. Let T ⁣:V→W\func{T}{V}{W}T:V→W, S ⁣:W→V\func{S}{W}{V}S:W→V be linear maps between vector spaces, where dim⁡V=dim⁡W=n<∞\dim{V} = \dim{W} = n < \inftydimV=dimW=n<∞. If T∘S=IWT \circ S = I_WT∘S=IW​, then TTT and SSS are both invertible with T=S−1T = S^{-1}T=S−1 and S=T−1S = T^{-1}S=T−1.

    To prove this, let's show that TTT is surjective. The proof is the same as before: let w∈Ww \in Ww∈W, and notice that

    (T∘S)(w)=IW(w)  ⟹  T(S(w))=w.\p{T \circ S}\p{w} = I_W\p{w} \implies T\p{S\p{w}} = w.(T∘S)(w)=IW​(w)⟹T(S(w))=w.

    As before, setting v=S(w)v = S\p{w}v=S(w) gives T(v)=wT\p{v} = wT(v)=w, so TTT is surjective, hence invertible. I'll reprove this here in case you haven't seen this fact:

    Because TTT is surjective, it follows that dim⁡R(T)=dim⁡W=n\dim R\p{T} = \dim W = ndimR(T)=dimW=n. Since VVV is finite-dimensional, we may apply rank-nullity to get

    dim⁡V=dim⁡R(T)+dim⁡N(T)  ⟹  n=n+dim⁡N(T)  ⟹  dim⁡N(T)=0  ⟹  N(T)={0},\begin{aligned} \dim V = \dim R\p{T} + \dim N\p{T} &\implies n = n + \dim N\p{T} \\ &\implies \dim N\p{T} = 0 \\ &\implies N\p{T} = \set{0}, \end{aligned}dimV=dimR(T)+dimN(T)​⟹n=n+dimN(T)⟹dimN(T)=0⟹N(T)={0},​

    so TTT is injective. Thus, TTT is a bijection, and the inverse of a linear map is linear, so TTT is an isomorphism. (Recall that isomorphism here means that TTT is a linear bijection and that T−1T^{-1}T−1 is a linear map.)

    The same calculations as above still work:

    T−1∘T∘S=T−1∘IW  ⟹  S=T−1  ⟹  S−1=(T−1)−1=T.T^{-1} \circ T \circ S = T^{-1} \circ I_W \implies S = T^{-1} \implies S^{-1} = \p{T^{-1}}^{-1} = T.T−1∘T∘S=T−1∘IW​⟹S=T−1⟹S−1=(T−1)−1=T.

Alternatively, you could have shown that BBB is injective, hence invertible.

Exercise 1.
